_prev_prog_3.Description:
Reddy Ice-Houston (312) has developed and implemented a combined Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program ("PSM/RMP") Program for it closed-circuit ammonia refrigeration system to address the accident prevention program requirements for both the Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration ("OSHA") regulations. 



The intent of the PSM/RMP Program is to identify and evaluate the hazardous of the ammonia refrigeration system to prevent the accidental releases of hazardous materials. The PSM/RMP Program is composed of fourteen performance-based elements, encompassed by a Management System to ensure the development, implementation, and integration of the program requirements. The PSM/RMP Program consists of the following elements, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractors, Pre-Startup Safety Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permits, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Planning and Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets. In addition, Reddy Ice-Houston (312) has developed a comprehensive Emergency Action Plan ("EAP"), which includes procedures for emergency notifications and the safe evacuation of employees.



Reddy Ice LLC is committed to operating a safe and regulatory compliant facility for the protection of its employees, the surrounding community, and the environment. The Reddy Ice-Houston (312) facility was designed with multiple safety systems for the ammonia refrigeration system. These safety systems include, but are not limited to, the following items, normal and emergency mechanical ventilation systems, emergency controls that shut down the equipment if operating limits are exceeded, and Programmable Logic Controller ("PLC") controls for system operation. Additionally, atmospheric refrigerant leak detection units and associated alarms are installed throughout the facility to notify employees or offsite personnel in the event of a fugitive ammonia release.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Reddy Ice LLC is dedicated to safe facility operations to ensure the protection of its employees, the surrounding community, and the environment. This commitment is integral to the effectiveness of the facility-specific programs and policies developed to prevent an accidental release of hazardous materials. The prevention of accidental releases has been provided for through the development and implementation of design and installation specifications, operating procedures, maintenance programs, employee training, and continuous improvement practices.



An accidental release prevention program intends to prevent the occurrence of a highly hazardous chemical incident or to minimize the potential consequences of an accidental release. In the event of a highly hazardous chemical incident or accidental release, employees, visitors, and contractors are trained to act following the facility-specific Emergency Action Plan ("EAP").



The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



Reddy Ice-Houston (312) located at 6004 North Shepherd Drive, Houston, Texas 77091, is a packaged ice manufacturing and storage facility. For this facility, the Risk Management Program ("RMP") regulated substance present is anhydrous ammonia (ammonia), which is utilized as a refrigerant for the closed-circuit mechanical refrigeration system. The closed-circuit ammonia refrigeration system provides process cooling for product manufacturing and refrigerated warehouse storage to maintain product quality. Ammonia, when properly used, has proven to be a safe, reliable, and efficient refrigerant, although, because of moderate toxicity and slight flammability, ammonia is considered a highly hazardous chemical.



Due to the operating inventories of the ammonia refrigeration system, this facility is covered under Program Level Three [3] requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's ("EPA") RMP regulation.



The Worst-Case

Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative-Case Release Scenario(s)



Reddy Ice LLC has conducted a comprehensive Hazard Assessment for the Reddy Ice-Houston (312) facility to determine and document the Offsite Consequence Analysis ("OCA") of potential worst-case and alternative-case release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration systems. The OCA describes the offsite exposure to surrounding areas, and the potentially affected offsite population and receptors from an accidental release of ammonia from the refrigeration system.



The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Reddy Ice LLC has taken all necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements established by 40 CFR Part 68 and 29 CFR 1910.119 through the development of a combined Process Safety Management and Risk Management ("PSM/RMP") Program for the ammonia refrigeration system in operation at the Reddy Ice-Houston (312) facility.



The PSM/RMP Program consists of fourteen performance-based elements, which are designed to reduce the likelihood and severity of an accidental release of ammonia from the refrigeration system. These elements include policies and procedures for Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractors, Pre-Startup Safety Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permits, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Planning and Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets. All program elements are encompassed by an established Management System that has been developed to ensure the development, implementation, and integration of the program requirements.



The following sections briefly describe the elements of the PSM/RMP Program established for Reddy Ice-Houston (312).



Employee Participation

The Employee Participation element provides the guidelines for involving employees in the development, implementation, and practice of th

e PSM/RMP Program. Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention and to recommend improvements. All employees have access to the PSM/RMP Program and related documents, including all facility-specific for the Process Hazard Analysis ("PHA") studies.



Process Safety Information

The Process Safety Information element provides the guideline for developing detailed information specific to the hazards of ammonia, the process technology, and the ammonia refrigeration system equipment. Information collection enables employers and employees to identify, understand, and plan for the hazards posed by the ammonia refrigeration system to improve processes, process safety, and emergency response. The compiled information shall be used for many purposes, such as developing procedures and training programs. The facility-specific information is used as a resource to support PHA studies.



Process Hazard Analysis

The Process Hazard Analysis element provides the guidelines for completing comprehensive analyses of the ammonia refrigeration system to ensure that potential hazards are identified and controlled efficiently. The analyses are conducted by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in refrigeration engineering and process operations and are re-evaluated at a minimum of every five [5] years. Any corrective actions required as a result of these studies shall be performed in a safe and timely manner.



Operating Procedures

The Operating Procedures element provides the guidelines and written procedures for safely conducting activities related to the ammonia refrigeration systems. These procedures address various modes of operation, including initial startup, normal startup, normal operations, emergency operations, temporary operations, normal shutdown, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, and startup following an emergency shutdown or turn around. The information is regularly reviewed for accuracy and is readily accessible

to all operators who work with the ammonia refrigeration system.



Training

The Training element provides the guidelines for establishing a comprehensive initial and refresher training program to ensure that authorized employees, who are working with the ammonia refrigeration system, are competent in all relevant operating procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every three [3] years and more frequently as needed.



Contractors

The Contractors element provides the procedures for selecting qualified contractors and evaluating safety performance when third-party work on, or around, the ammonia refrigeration system is required. Contractors shall be informed of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work with the ammonia refrigeration system, as well as the procedures for emergency action in the event of an accidental ammonia release.



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews

The Pre-Startup Safety Review element provides the guidelines for reviewing startup safety any time the ammonia refrigeration system or any of its components, are opened for repairs, tie-ins, or modifications. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.



Mechanical Integrity

The Mechanical Integrity element provides the guidelines and written procedures for maintaining, inspecting, and testing the ammonia refrigeration system equipment to ensure proper operations. Process equipment examined by these checks includes but are not limited to the following components:  pressure vessels, piping systems, pressure relief valves, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in the applicable maintenance practices.



Hot Work Permits

The Hot Work Permit element provides the guidelines for controlling welding and hot work activities on, or around, the amm

onia refrigeration system. Hot work is monitored and managed through a permitting process to ensure individual qualification, a safe environment, and fire watch provisions as necessary.



Management of Change

The Management of Change element provides guidelines for managing changes, including replacement-in-kind, in the ammonia refrigeration system technology, equipment, and procedures. Authorized employees whose job tasks are affected by an ammonia refrigeration system modification are promptly made aware of and offered training for the modification.



Incident Investigation

The Incident Investigation element provides the guidelines for promptly investigating an incident that has resulted in or could have reasonably resulted in an unintentional release of ammonia. These investigation procedures identify the situation leading to the incident, determine root-cause, and define any corrective actions implemented to prevent the release from reoccurring. All incident investigation reports are retained for a minimum of five [5] years.



Emergency Planning and Response

The Emergency Planning and Response element provides the guidelines for planning and responding to an ammonia incident. Emergency planning and response provisions include procedures for emergency notifications, employee training, and safe evacuation of personnel. All emergency planning and response documents are reviewed regularly for verification of data and revised and updated as necessary to reflect changes in facility operations and personnel.



Compliance Audits

The Compliance Audit element provides the guidelines for conducting periodic audits of the PSM/RMP Program to determine whether the provisions set out under the Federal and, as applicable, State regulations are implemented. A comprehensive audit of the PSM/RMP Program is to be completed at least every three [3] years. Any corrective actions required as a result of these audits shall be performed in a safe and timely manner.



Trade Secr

ets

The Trade Secrets element provides the guidelines for maintaining confidential business information concerning the ammonia refrigeration system and its safe operation.



Five-Year Accident History



Reddy Ice LLC has thoroughly investigated any incident involving the closed-circuit mechanical refrigeration system in operation at the Reddy Ice-Houston (312) facility, which resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of ammonia.



No incident involving an ammonia release has resulted in onsite deaths, onsite injuries, significant onsite property damage, known offsite deaths, known offsite injuries, known offsite evacuations, known offsite sheltering-in-place, known offsite property damage, or known offsite environmental damage. Reddy Ice-Houston (312) has not had any ammonia releases that would require reporting as part of the five-year accident history.



Emergency Response Program



In the event of an ammonia release incident or emergency, Reddy Ice-Houston (312) has trained its employees to act according to the facility-specific EAP. The EAP includes procedures for the notification of emergency authorities/agencies and the surrounding community, the evacuation of facility personnel, and the first responder duties for trained employees.



If an emergency response is required, Reddy Ice-Houston (312) has coordinated with the local area hazardous materials incident response team. This periodic coordination is to ensure local responder awareness of the facility and ammonia refrigeration system, and the limited employee response capacity for the Reddy Ice-Houston (312) facility.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Reddy Ice LLC utilizes the PSM/RMP Program as a continuous improvement practice to enhance ammonia refrigeration system safety through employee involvement, employee training, maintenance practices, and hazard studies. As such, the ammonia refrigeration system in operation at the Reddy Ice-Houston (312) facility is de

signed, installed, and operated with multiple safety systems per industry-specific recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices ("RAGAGEP"). These safety systems include, but are not limited to, the following items, normal and emergency mechanical ventilation systems, emergency controls that shut down the equipment if operating limits are exceeded, and Programmable Logic Controller ("PLC") control for system operation. Additionally, atmospheric refrigerant leak detection units and associated alarms are installed throughout the facility to notify employees or offsite personnel in the event of a fugitive ammonia release.



At this time, no significant changes are planned for the facility or ammonia refrigeration system. Reddy Ice-Houston (312) operates an ongoing program of preventive and predictive maintenance to identify and implement changes that may result in improved safety and operations for the ammonia refrigeration systems. Any corrective actions identified as a result of maintenance activities or PSM/RMP Program practices shall be performed in a safe and timely manner.
